settings.text: Long-time friend of Chinti & Parker, Ginnie Chadwyck-Healey worked at British Vogue for 12 years before setting up VCH Style where she consults for luxury brands of all sizes. Also offering styling advice through her weekly column for the Sunday Telegraph, she aims to educate readers to shop in a more sustainable and savvy fashion. We learned some of her top tips when we caught up. Read on to find out more.

settings.grid-content:
How would you describe your personal style?

I would say it's colourful, confident, and considered.

How has the pandemic affected the way you shop for clothes? And the way you dress from day to day?

I had just had a baby when we began our first lockdown so naturally, I was more casual and focused on lower maintenance looks. But clothes definitely change my mindset from an okay day to a 'let's go for it' vibe so I employ colour to do that. Not necessarily bold colours, but great pairings. Green and pink, navy and tobacco, powder blue and army green. Most of all my clothes never get in the way of my routine. So, the shift to loungewear was very much welcomed but I always ensure I combine comfort with structure. Like a boyfriend jean with a blazer. Trainers and jeans but with a silk shirt. I could never do the whole daytime pyjama look! To be honest I knew, pre-Covid, that we could all live with far less. So, if anything this past year has only cemented my business strategy, which in some weird way I'm thankful for.

What would be your advice to others looking to make more sustainable choices when it comes to shopping for clothes?

Read your labels! It's not enough to assume you are shopping from a brand that says they are doing good or planting x number of trees, or working with x charities. I think we have to start understanding the ingredients of our clothes.



“Clothes definitely change my mindset from an okay day to a 'let's go for it' vibe so I employ colour to do that.”

What are you looking forward to wearing this summer?

I am really excited to see everyone up the ante a little. Not only because we are all ready to come out again but because I think lots of people won't go abroad so it will be interesting to see how we experiment with our staycation wardrobes (here in the UK) and navigate the temperamental British weather! For me, I'm looking forward to bold tops and shirts, and some great dungarees in a range of fabrics.


Which three pieces from your wardrobe do you rely on most?

My Chloé dungarees dress. My Church's loafers. My favourite Chinti & Parker navy cardigan from about 2018, it has embroidery on the back.

settings.text:
My Loewe coat. I would never have been able to afford it full price. I saw it, it sang to me, I pounced. Now I get stopped in the street for it. It was also the coat I bought when I started www.vchstyle.com so it feels symbolic of the post Vogue chapter of my career.



Which Chinti & Parker pieces do you have your eye on this season? And what do you love about them?

I'm loving these three knits (pictured) because there is such a variety of looks for all eventualities. So I can envisage wearing these pieces well into the autumn, even winter, with extra layers. I really have to ensure there is longevity to my wardrobe choices. It's about thinking 'Will I still love this after its first outing?' as we are all exposed to so much newness every single day, it can feel like we are constantly in need of something new. Really, I love the striped Jeanne top the most. Classic but with a Chinti twist thanks to the orange baseline.
